entry.title: words-fourth-day
entry.content:
释义列表

  1. cunning - adj./n.

    • paraphrase：clever at deceiving others
    • synonym：sly, crafty
    • example：Although the fox was cunning, it couldn’t escape the trap that the farmer had set near the fence.

  2. burst - v./n.

    • paraphrase：break open suddenly or explode
    • synonym：explode, rupture
    • example：The balloon burst when it touched the thorny bush, which startled the children playing nearby.

  3. superfluous - adj.

    • paraphrase：more than needed; unnecessary
    • synonym：excess, extra
    • example：The teacher asked us to remove superfluous details from the report so it would be clearer.

  4. qualitative - adj.

    • paraphrase：related to quality rather than quantity
    • synonym：descriptive, subjective
    • example：The study focused on qualitative data, such as personal experiences, while ignoring numbers.

  5. dismiss - v.

    • paraphrase：send away or reject as unimportant
    • synonym：reject, disregard
    • example：The manager dismissed the idea because it was too costly, even though the team supported it.

  6. ceiling - n.

    • paraphrase：upper interior surface of a room
    • synonym：roof, upper limit
    • example：The ceiling of the old house had cracks, which let in cold air during winter storms.

  7. architecture - n.

    • paraphrase：design style of buildings
    • synonym：structure, design
    • example：Gothic architecture uses tall spires, which symbolize a connection to heaven.

  8. relieve - v.

    • paraphrase：reduce pain or stress
    • synonym：ease, alleviate
    • example：The medicine relieved her headache, so she could finish her work before the deadline.

  9. visual - adj.

    • paraphrase：related to sight
    • synonym：visible, optical
    • example：The visual effects in the movie were stunning, although the plot was confusing.

  10. perspective - n.

    • paraphrase：way of viewing something
    • synonym：viewpoint, angle
    • example：From his perspective, the plan was perfect, but others saw flaws in it.

  11. desperate - adj.

    • paraphrase：extremely needing or hopeless
    • synonym：urgent, hopeless
    • example：They were desperate for food after the storm destroyed their crops.

  12. variable - adj./n.

    • paraphrase：likely to change; a changing factor
    • synonym：unstable, factor
    • example：The experiment’s results were variable because the temperature fluctuated daily.

  13. endeavor - n./v.

    • paraphrase：try hard to achieve something
    • synonym：attempt, effort
    • example：She endeavored to finish the project on time, even though the team faced many delays.

  14. jurisdiction - n.

    • paraphrase：legal authority over an area
    • synonym：authority, control
    • example：The crime occurred outside the police’s jurisdiction, so they couldn’t investigate it.

  15. questionnaire - n.

    • paraphrase：set of written questions for research
    • synonym：survey, form
    • example：Participants filled out a questionnaire to share their opinions about the new policy.

  16. underlie - v.

    • paraphrase：be the hidden cause of something
    • synonym：base, support
    • example：Economic inequality underlies many social conflicts that governments struggle to resolve.

  17. prolong - v.

    • paraphrase：make something last longer
    • synonym：extend, lengthen
    • example：The doctor warned that smoking would prolong his recovery from the illness.

  18. presently - adv.

    • paraphrase：soon or currently
    • synonym：shortly, now
    • example：She is presently working on the report, which she will submit by tomorrow morning.

  19. launch - v./n.

    • paraphrase：start or introduce something new
    • synonym：begin, initiate
    • example：The company will launch its new product next month if the final tests are successful.

  20. scrutiny - n.

    • paraphrase：close examination or criticism
    • synonym：inspection, analysis
    • example：The proposal faced intense scrutiny because its costs were unusually high.

  21. urban - adj.

    • paraphrase：related to cities
    • synonym：city, metropolitan
    • example：Urban areas often struggle with traffic congestion, which rural regions rarely experience.

  22. instinct - n.

    • paraphrase：natural behavior or feeling
    • synonym：intuition, impulse
    • example：Her instinct told her to avoid the dark alley, where strange noises echoed at night.

  23. peculiar - adj.

    • paraphrase：strange or unusual
    • synonym：odd, bizarre
    • example：The cat’s peculiar habit of staring at the wall puzzled everyone in the house.

  24. undergo - v.

    • paraphrase：experience something (often difficult)
    • synonym：endure, experience
    • example：The patient will undergo surgery tomorrow if the doctors approve the procedure.

  25. enrol - v.

    • paraphrase：officially join a course or group
    • synonym：register, join
    • example：Students must enrol in the program before the deadline, which is next Friday.

  26. elsewhere - adv.

    • paraphrase：in or to another place
    • synonym：somewhere else, away
    • example：The store was out of stock, so we had to look elsewhere for the ingredients.

  27. panorama - n.

    • paraphrase：wide view of an area
    • synonym：vista, view
    • example：From the hilltop, we saw a panorama of the valley, where rivers cut through forests.

  28. lateral - adj.

    • paraphrase：related to the side
    • synonym：sideways, side
    • example：The car suffered lateral damage when it was hit from the right side.

  29. shore - n.

    • paraphrase：land along the edge of a sea/lake
    • synonym：coast, beach
    • example：We walked along the shore, where waves crashed against the rocks loudly.

  30. frequent - adj./v.

    • paraphrase：① (adj.) happening often; ② (v.) visit often
    • synonym：① regular; ② visit
    • example：He frequents the café downtown because the coffee there is exceptionally good.

  31. chart - n./v.

    • paraphrase：① (n.) visual data display; ② (v.) map or plan
    • synonym：① graph; ② map
    • example：The chart showed sales trends, which helped the team adjust their strategy.

  32. republican - adj./n.

    • paraphrase：supporting a republic system
    • synonym：democratic (context-dependent)
    • example：The republican candidate promised tax reforms, which appealed to middle-class voters.

  33. tactic - n.

    • paraphrase：planned action to achieve a goal
    • synonym：strategy, approach
    • example：Their negotiation tactic was to stay silent until the other side made an offer.

  34. aside - adv./n.

    • paraphrase：① to one side; ② (n.) remark in a play
    • synonym：① apart; ② comment
    • example：She pushed her worries aside and focused on finishing the project before noon.

  35. span - n./v.

    • paraphrase：length of time or space
    • synonym：duration, extend
    • example：The bridge’s span was impressive, stretching over a mile across the river.

  36. ritual - n./adj.

    • paraphrase：ceremony or routine
    • synonym：ceremony, tradition
    • example：Morning coffee became a ritual for him, even when he was traveling.

  37. stock - n./v.

    • paraphrase：① supply of goods; ② (v.) keep goods available
    • synonym：① inventory; ② supply
    • example：The store ran out of stock for the new phone, which disappointed many customers.

  38. incur - v.

    • paraphrase：experience something unpleasant (e.g., debt)
    • synonym：suffer, acquire
    • example：Delaying repairs will incur higher costs later if the damage worsens.

  39. commission - n./v.

    • paraphrase：① (n.) fee or official task; ② (v.) hire someone
    • synonym：① fee; ② hire
    • example：The artist received a commission to paint a mural for the city hall.

  40. forth - adv.

    • paraphrase：forward in time or place
    • synonym：forward, onward
    • example：He paced back and forth in the room while waiting for the test results.

  41. latter - adj.

    • paraphrase：second of two things mentioned
    • synonym：second, last
    • example：Between tea and coffee, she preferred the latter because of its stronger flavor.

  42. organic - adj.

    • paraphrase：natural, without artificial chemicals
    • synonym：natural, pure
    • example：Organic vegetables cost more, but they are grown without synthetic pesticides.

  43. revive - v.

    • paraphrase：bring back to life or consciousness
    • synonym：restore, renew
    • example：The rain revived the dying plants, which had wilted during the drought.

  44. campus - n.

    • paraphrase：university grounds
    • synonym：school grounds, site
    • example：The new library on campus has study rooms where students can work in groups.

  45. conversely - adv.

    • paraphrase：in an opposite way
    • synonym：oppositely, inversely
    • example：Some people love spicy food; conversely, others avoid it completely.

  46. zone - n.

    • paraphrase：area with specific features or rules
    • synonym：area, region
    • example：The factory was built in an industrial zone, where residential buildings are banned.

  47. avail - n./v.

    • paraphrase：use or benefit
    • synonym：use, help
    • example：He tried to fix the leak himself, but his efforts were to no avail.

  48. precaution - n.

    • paraphrase：action to prevent harm
    • synonym：safeguard, measure
    • example：Wearing a helmet is a precaution that reduces head injuries during accidents.

  49. surplus - n./adj.

    • paraphrase：extra amount beyond what’s needed
    • synonym：excess, extra
    • example：The farm produced a surplus of wheat, which they sold to neighboring countries.

  50. rhetoric - n.

    • paraphrase：persuasive speech or writing
    • synonym：oratory, persuasion
    • example：Politicians often use rhetoric to sway public opinion, even if their claims are exaggerated.

entry.title: words-sixth-day
entry.content:
释义列表

  1. evaluate - v.
    ◦ paraphrase：judge the value or quality of something
    ◦ synonym：assess, judge
    ◦ example：The teacher will evaluate our projects tomorrow, which makes everyone nervous about their grades.

  2. console - v.
    ◦ paraphrase：comfort someone in distress
    ◦ synonym：comfort, soothe
    ◦ example：She tried to console her friend after the loss, even though she felt helpless herself.

  3. assassinate - v.
    ◦ paraphrase：murder a prominent person for political reasons
    ◦ synonym：kill, murder
    ◦ example：The plot to assassinate the leader failed when guards discovered the hidden weapons.

  4. expire - v.
    ◦ paraphrase：come to an end; die
    ◦ synonym：end, terminate
    ◦ example：My passport expires next month, so I need to renew it before traveling.

  5. confine - v.
    ◦ paraphrase：keep within limits; restrict
    ◦ synonym：restrict, limit
    ◦ example：The doctor confined him to bed rest until his fever subsided.

  6. conception - n.
    ◦ paraphrase：idea or understanding; beginning of pregnancy
    ◦ synonym：idea, notion
    ◦ example：The conception of the project was brilliant, but poor execution ruined it.

  7. betray - v.
    ◦ paraphrase：be disloyal; reveal secrets
    ◦ synonym：deceive, expose
    ◦ example：He felt betrayed when his best friend shared his secret with others.

  8. shade - n./v.
    ◦ paraphrase：① (n.) slight darkness from blocking light; ② (v.) protect from light
    ◦ synonym：shadow, cover
    ◦ example：They sat under the shade of a tree where the sunlight couldn’t reach them.

  9. anticipate - v.
    ◦ paraphrase：expect or prepare for something
    ◦ synonym：expect, foresee
    ◦ example：We anticipated heavy traffic, so we left home an hour earlier than usual.

  10. concentrate - v.
    ◦ paraphrase：focus all attention on something
    ◦ synonym：focus, center
    ◦ example：I can’t concentrate on my work if the TV is blaring in the next room.

  11. stuff - n./v.
    ◦ paraphrase：① (n.) unnamed things; ② (v.) fill tightly
    ◦ synonym：things, fill
    ◦ example：She packed all her stuff into boxes before moving to the new apartment.

  12. emit - v.
    ◦ paraphrase：send out (e.g., light, sound, gas)
    ◦ synonym：release, discharge
    ◦ example：The factory emits harmful gases, which pollute the surrounding villages.

  13. encounter - v./n.
    ◦ paraphrase：meet unexpectedly; experience
    ◦ synonym：meet, face
    ◦ example：They encountered a snake while hiking, which made them turn back immediately.

  14. guideline - n.
    ◦ paraphrase：rule or advice for action
    ◦ synonym：rule, instruction
    ◦ example：Follow the safety guidelines when handling chemicals to avoid accidents.

  15. outrage - n./v.
    ◦ paraphrase：extreme anger; cause anger
    ◦ synonym：anger, fury
    ◦ example：The unfair verdict sparked public outrage, leading to protests in the city.

  16. advertise - v.
    ◦ paraphrase：promote a product/service publicly
    ◦ synonym：promote, market
    ◦ example：The company advertised the new phone on social media, where most users are active.

  17. politician - n.
    ◦ paraphrase：person active in government
    ◦ synonym：leader, statesman
    ◦ example：The politician promised tax reforms, but critics doubted his sincerity.

  18. regard - v./n.
    ◦ paraphrase：consider or respect; attention
    ◦ synonym：consider, respect
    ◦ example：She is highly regarded in her field because of her groundbreaking research.

  19. trumpet - n./v.
    ◦ paraphrase：① (n.) brass musical instrument; ② (v.) announce loudly
    ◦ synonym：horn, proclaim
    ◦ example：The elephant trumpeted loudly, which scared the birds into flying away.

  20. loom - v.
    ◦ paraphrase：appear as a large unclear shape; threaten
    ◦ synonym：emerge, threaten
    ◦ example：Dark clouds loomed overhead, so we hurried home before the storm began.

  21. bare - adj./v.
    ◦ paraphrase：① (adj.) uncovered; ② (v.) expose
    ◦ synonym：naked, reveal
    ◦ example：His bare feet left prints on the sandy beach where the waves washed ashore.

  22. applicable - adj.
    ◦ paraphrase：relevant or suitable
    ◦ synonym：relevant, suitable
    ◦ example：This rule is only applicable to employees who joined after 2020.

  23. interact - v.
    ◦ paraphrase：communicate or act with others
    ◦ synonym：communicate, engage
    ◦ example：Children learn to interact with peers when they attend school regularly.

  24. conscience - n.
    ◦ paraphrase：inner sense of right and wrong
    ◦ synonym：morality, ethics
    ◦ example：His conscience stopped him from lying, even though it would have helped him.

  25. remark - n./v.
    ◦ paraphrase：comment or notice
    ◦ synonym：comment, note
    ◦ example：She made a sarcastic remark about his outfit, which embarrassed him in public.

  26. correspond - v.
    ◦ paraphrase：match or exchange letters
    ◦ synonym：match, communicate
    ◦ example：His actions don’t correspond with his words, which makes him untrustworthy.

  27. masterpiece - n.
    ◦ paraphrase：work of outstanding skill
    ◦ synonym：masterwork, gem
    ◦ example：The novel is considered a masterpiece because it redefined modern literature.

  28. permit - v./n.
    ◦ paraphrase：allow; official document allowing action
    ◦ synonym：allow, license
    ◦ example：You need a permit to park here, or your car will be towed by the authorities.

  29. glamour - n.
    ◦ paraphrase：attractive excitement or charm
    ◦ synonym：charm, allure
    ◦ example：The glamour of Hollywood often hides the struggles actors face behind the scenes.

  30. shield - n./v.
    ◦ paraphrase：protective cover; protect from harm
    ◦ synonym：protect, guard
    ◦ example：The lawyer shielded her client from aggressive questions during the trial.

  31. radiant - adj.
    ◦ paraphrase：shining brightly; very happy
    ◦ synonym：glowing, bright
    ◦ example：The bride looked radiant in her white dress as she walked down the aisle.

  32. prominent - adj.
    ◦ paraphrase：important; easily seen
    ◦ synonym：famous, noticeable
    ◦ example：The prominent scientist was invited to speak at the conference about climate change.

  33. enthusiastic - adj.
    ◦ paraphrase：showing intense excitement
    ◦ synonym：eager, passionate
    ◦ example：The team was enthusiastic about the new project, which boosted their productivity.

  34. comprehend - v.
    ◦ paraphrase：understand fully
    ◦ synonym：understand, grasp
    ◦ example：The textbook was too advanced for the students to comprehend without the teacher’s help.

  35. thrive - v.
    ◦ paraphrase：grow or develop well
    ◦ synonym：flourish, prosper
    ◦ example：Plants thrive in this greenhouse where temperature and humidity are controlled.

  36. subtle - adj.
    ◦ paraphrase：not obvious; delicate
    ◦ synonym：slight, delicate
    ◦ example：The painting’s subtle colors create a calming effect that viewers find soothing.

  37. deliver - v.
    ◦ paraphrase：bring goods; give a speech
    ◦ synonym：transport, present
    ◦ example：The courier promised to deliver the package by noon, but it arrived late.

  38. bound - adj./v.
    ◦ paraphrase：① (adj.) certain; ② (v.) jump
    ◦ synonym：certain, leap
    ◦ example：He’s bound to succeed because he works harder than anyone else in the team.

  39. extravagant - adj.
    ◦ paraphrase：spending too much; excessive
    ◦ synonym：wasteful, excessive
    ◦ example：She criticized his extravagant spending on luxury cars while his debts piled up.

  40. accuse - v.
    ◦ paraphrase：claim someone did something wrong
    ◦ synonym：blame, charge
    ◦ example：The manager was accused of favoritism, which caused tension in the office.

  41. conceal - v.
    ◦ paraphrase：hide something
    ◦ synonym：hide, cover
    ◦ example：He tried to conceal his disappointment when he failed the interview.

  42. slack - adj./n.
    ◦ paraphrase：① (adj.) loose; lazy; ② (n.) loose part
    ◦ synonym：loose, lazy
    ◦ example：The rope went slack after the weight was removed, which made it easier to coil.

  43. alternative - n./adj.
    ◦ paraphrase：another option; different
    ◦ synonym：option, substitute
    ◦ example：If the bus is late, we can take the alternative route through the park.

  44. mortgage - n./v.
    ◦ paraphrase：loan for buying property
    ◦ synonym：loan, debt
    ◦ example：They took out a mortgage to buy the house where they plan to raise their children.

  45. devote - v.
    ◦ paraphrase：dedicate time/effort to something
    ◦ synonym：dedicate, commit
    ◦ example：She devoted her life to charity work, which earned her widespread respect.

  46. grand - adj.
    ◦ paraphrase：impressive in size or style
    ◦ synonym：magnificent, splendid
    ◦ example：The grand palace attracted tourists who marveled at its architecture.

  47. dominate - v.
    ◦ paraphrase：control or overpower
    ◦ synonym：control, rule
    ◦ example：The team dominated the match from start to finish, leaving no chance for the opponent.

  48. exclude - v.
    ◦ paraphrase：leave out intentionally
    ◦ synonym：omit, reject
    ◦ example：They excluded him from the meeting because his input wasn’t necessary.

  49. collide - v.
    ◦ paraphrase：crash into forcefully
    ◦ synonym：crash, clash
    ◦ example：The two cars collided at the intersection where the traffic lights were broken.

  50. plausible - adj.
    ◦ paraphrase：seeming reasonable or true
    ◦ synonym：believable, credible
    ◦ example：His excuse sounded plausible, but no one could confirm his alibi.

单词列表

  1. evaluate
  2. console
  3. assassinate
  4. expire
  5. confine
  6. conception
  7. betray
  8. shade
  9. anticipate
  10. concentrate
  11. stuff

  14. guideline

entry.title: words-fifth-day
entry.content:
释义列表

  1. comedy - n.

    • paraphrase：funny play or film
    • synonym：humor, farce
    • example：The comedy was so amusing that the audience laughed even when the actors forgot their lines.

  2. consumption - n.

    • paraphrase：act of using up resources
    • synonym：use, expenditure
    • example：The government urged people to reduce energy consumption because power plants were overloaded.

  3. defeat - v./n.

    • paraphrase：win against someone; failure
    • synonym：beat, overcome
    • example：If we defeat this team, we’ll advance to the finals, which is our ultimate goal.

  4. confess - v.

    • paraphrase：admit wrongdoing
    • synonym：admit, acknowledge
    • example：He confessed to stealing the money, but his family refused to believe it.

  5. enterprise - n.

    • paraphrase：business project or company
    • synonym：company, venture
    • example：The new enterprise aims to provide jobs in areas where unemployment is high.

  6. locality - n.

    • paraphrase：specific area or neighborhood
    • synonym：region, district
    • example：The new park is located in a quiet locality where residents often walk their dogs.

  7. fare - n./v.

    • paraphrase：① (n.) money paid for travel; ② (v.) perform
    • synonym：① ticket price; ② manage
    • example：Bus fares increased last week, which made daily commuting more expensive.

  8. comprise - v.

    • paraphrase：consist of
    • synonym：include, contain
    • example：The committee comprises experts from various fields who meet monthly.

  9. alter - v.

    • paraphrase：change slightly
    • synonym：modify, adjust
    • example：She had to alter her dress because it was too long to wear to the party.

  10. clue - n.

    • paraphrase：hint to solve a problem
    • synonym：hint, sign
    • example：The detective found a clue under the table, which led him to the suspect.

  11. endorse - v.

    • paraphrase：publicly support
    • synonym：approve, support
    • example：The celebrity endorsed the product, which boosted its sales immediately.

  12. alternation - n.

    • paraphrase：repeated change between states
    • synonym：shift, switch
    • example：The alternation between hot and cold weather confused the plants’ growth cycles.

  13. relief - n.

    • paraphrase：feeling of comfort after stress
    • synonym：ease, comfort
    • example：She sighed with relief when she heard her son was safe after the accident.

  14. mentor - n./v.

    • paraphrase：experienced advisor
    • synonym：guide, teacher
    • example：Her mentor taught her negotiation skills, which helped her secure the deal.

  15. economical - adj.

    • paraphrase：saving money or resources
    • synonym：thrifty, efficient
    • example：The car is economical on fuel, which makes it ideal for long trips.

  16. savage - adj./n.

    • paraphrase：extremely violent or cruel
    • synonym：brutal, fierce
    • example：The savage storm destroyed houses that had stood for decades.

  17. airline - n.

    • paraphrase：company providing air transport
    • synonym：carrier, aviation
    • example：The airline canceled flights due to fog, which stranded hundreds of passengers.

  18. toss - v.

    • paraphrase：throw lightly
    • synonym：throw, fling
    • example：He tossed the keys onto the table before collapsing onto the sofa.

  19. soak - v.

    • paraphrase：make completely wet
    • synonym：drench, saturate
    • example：If you soak the beans overnight, they’ll cook faster the next day.

  20. tropical - adj.

    • paraphrase：related to hot, humid regions
    • synonym：equatorial, lush
    • example：Tropical fruits like mangoes grow abundantly in areas near the equator.

  21. sector - n.

    • paraphrase：section of an economy or area
    • synonym：division, zone
    • example：The technology sector is booming, which attracts many investors.

  22. negligible - adj.

    • paraphrase：too small to matter
    • synonym：insignificant, minor
    • example：The error in the report was negligible, so no one bothered to correct it.

  23. disgrace - n./v.

    • paraphrase：loss of respect; shame
    • synonym：shame, dishonor
    • example：The scandal brought disgrace to his family, who had always been respected.

  24. amend - v.

    • paraphrase：make small improvements
    • synonym：revise, correct
    • example：The law was amended to protect workers’ rights after protests erupted.

  25. favor - n./v.

    • paraphrase：kind act; prefer
    • synonym：kindness, support
    • example：She asked me for a favor because she couldn’t finish the task alone.

  26. conceive - v.

    • paraphrase：form an idea or become pregnant
    • synonym：imagine, devise
    • example：He conceived the plan while sitting in the park where he often relaxed.

  27. victim - n.

    • paraphrase：person harmed by an action
    • synonym：casualty, sufferer
    • example：The victim of the scam lost all his savings, which left him devastated.

  28. gross - adj.

    • paraphrase：total before deductions; disgusting
    • synonym：total, vulgar
    • example：The gross income of the company rose, but profits fell due to high costs.

  29. sovereign - n./adj.

    • paraphrase：supreme ruler; independent
    • synonym：monarch, supreme
    • example：The sovereign power of the nation lies with its people, not a single ruler.

  30. render - v.

    • paraphrase：cause to be; provide
    • synonym：make, give
    • example：The storm rendered the roads impassable, which delayed rescue teams.

  31. premium - n./adj.

    • paraphrase：high-quality; extra payment
    • synonym：superior, extra
    • example：Customers pay a premium for organic products because they’re healthier.

  32. evade - v.

    • paraphrase：escape or avoid cleverly
    • synonym：avoid, dodge
    • example：The politician evaded the question when asked about corruption.

  33. illustrate - v.

    • paraphrase：explain with examples or images
    • synonym：demonstrate, show
    • example：The teacher used diagrams to illustrate how the human heart works.

  34. restrict - v.

    • paraphrase：limit movement or action
    • synonym：limit, confine
    • example：The law restricts smoking in public places to protect non-smokers.

  35. stereotype - n./v.

    • paraphrase：fixed oversimplified idea
    • synonym：cliché, generalize
    • example：The film broke the stereotype that heroes must always be physically strong.

  36. conservation - n.

    • paraphrase：protection of natural resources
    • synonym：preservation, protection
    • example：Conservation efforts saved the forest where endangered species live.

  37. contract - n./v.

    • paraphrase：legal agreement; shrink
    • synonym：agreement, shrink
    • example：She signed a contract that requires her to work for the company for two years.

  38. suspicious - adj.

    • paraphrase：doubtful or distrustful
    • synonym：doubtful, wary
    • example：The suspicious package was reported to the police, who evacuated the area.

  39. expertise - n.

    • paraphrase：specialized knowledge
    • synonym：skill, knowledge
    • example：His expertise in engineering helped solve the bridge’s design flaw.

  40. ethnic - adj.

    • paraphrase：related to cultural groups
    • synonym：cultural, racial
    • example：The festival celebrates ethnic traditions that have been passed down for generations.

  41. vessel - n.

    • paraphrase：ship or container; blood tube
    • synonym：ship, container
    • example：The vessel carried medical supplies to the island where hospitals were understaffed.

  42. safeguard - v./n.

    • paraphrase：protect from harm
    • synonym：protect, defense
    • example：Regular backups safeguard data in case the computer system crashes.

  43. biography - n.

    • paraphrase：story of a person’s life
    • synonym：life story, memoir
    • example：The biography revealed secrets about the author’s childhood that shocked readers.

  44. abolish - v.

    • paraphrase：officially end a system
    • synonym：eliminate, end
    • example：The government abolished the tax after protests erupted across the country.

  45. pension - n.

    • paraphrase：regular payment after retirement
    • synonym：retirement fund, allowance
    • example：He relies on his pension to cover living costs since he stopped working.

  46. conductor - n.

    • paraphrase：person directing music; material transmitting electricity
    • synonym：director, leader
    • example：The conductor raised his baton, and the orchestra began playing.

  47. firm - adj./n.

    • paraphrase：solid; company
    • synonym：hard, company
    • example：The mattress was too firm, so she couldn’t sleep comfortably.

  48. purse - n./v.

    • paraphrase：small bag for money; tighten lips
    • synonym：handbag, clutch
    • example：She lost her purse while shopping, which contained her ID and credit cards.

  49. attach - v.

    • paraphrase：fasten or join
    • synonym：fix, connect
    • example：Attach the file to the email before sending it to the manager.

  50. irony - n.

    • paraphrase：opposite of what’s expected
    • synonym：sarcasm, paradox
    • example：The irony is that the fire station burned down while firefighters were on vacation.

单词列表

  1. comedy
  2. consumption
  3. defeat
  4. confess

entry.title: 二重积分、三重积分、重积分应用
entry.content:
二重积分的计算法

直角坐标


以这道题说明方法
先对Y积分，因为Y的范围一下就看出来了，而且对X的范围用y表示的时候也比较方便
∫−12dy∫y2y+2dx\int_{-1}^{2}dy\int_{y^2}^{y+2}dx∫−12​dy∫y2y+2​dx
也可以换一下积分顺序，但是比较麻烦

有的原函数不能用初等函数表示，所以积分顺序是唯一的，弄错了就积不出来

利用对称性和奇偶性简化计算

积分区域关于x轴对称时，被积函数是关于y的奇函数可以抵消，偶函数翻倍
关于y轴对称时也一样
以a(x,y)=2x2ya(x,y)=2 x^2 ya(x,y)=2x2y的图像进行说明，不想死记公式，公式记多不仅痛苦还容易忘

积分区域关于x轴对称，关于y的奇函数，一半体积向上，一半向下，抵消了

极坐标

对x和y的积分变成了对θ和ρ的积分
判断θ的范围：以x轴的正方向为标准，从0开始，π2\frac{π}{2}2π​到y轴的正方向，−π2-\frac{π}{2}−2π​到y轴的负方向，看转多少范围可以把积分区域包起来，范围就是多少，转一圈才能把积分区域包起来的话，那就是0 ~ 2π
判断ρ的范围：如果积分区域是一个以原点为中心的圆，那ρ的范围就是0 ~ ρ，如果积分区域是一个与坐标轴相切的圆，那ρ的范围就是0 ~ 直径乘上cos θ或者sin θ

用极坐标积分的时候，dρdρdρ前边一定要加一个ρ！！！，写成ρdρρdρρdρ，好烦，又是一个死记的小东西

三重积分的计算法

超级可恶的知识点，积分区域还得考想象

直角坐标

投影法
看情况把积分区域投影到坐标轴的平面
举个例子：积分区域为z=x2+y2,y=x2,y=1,z=0z=x^2+y^2,y=x^2,y=1,z=0z=x2+y2,y=x2,y=1,z=0
我感觉积分区域贴着哪个平面就把这个投影都哪个平面
画出x，y的坐标轴，然后以这个坐标轴为地基想象那个图形
看xoy平面的投影，x的范围是[-1,1],y的范围从左边x2x^2x2开始到y=1结束，[x2,1][x^2,1][x2,1],z的区域是从下平面到上平面，[0,x2+y2][0,x^2+y^2][0,x2+y2]
截面法
找出来一个和坐标轴围成的那三个平面平行的一个截面，然后对垂直那个平面的坐标轴的参数积分，我去，天呐，我在乌拉什么，希望明天我能看懂
算了，放一个题叭

其实就是算一个截面的面积，然后对最后一个参数积分

对称性和奇偶性

关于xoy平面对称时，被积函数是关于z的奇函数，积分相消，偶函数翻倍
我好想找到文字规律了，但是我还是不理解为啥，不像一元函数积分那样直观，画个图就能看见
关于y对称，那就看被积函数的x
关于xoy对称，那就看被积函数的z
有你没我，有我没你定理

柱面坐标

柱面坐标像是极坐标和直角坐标的结合，底面用极坐标表示，就一个z轴用直角坐标积分
ρdρdθdzρdρdθdzρdρdθdz
θ的取值范围还是用一个能够包住底面图形的范围表示
ρ的取值在以原点为圆心的底面时范围在0~腰围最大的那一圈在底面投影的长度
圆心不在原点的话，范围还跟极坐标那个一样
z的取值范围，从下底面到顶面，还是用ρ表示的

球面坐标

这个用r来代替ρ了，r sin φ等于投影到底面的长度
这个长度乘以cos θ是x，乘以sin θ是y
z就是直接r cos φ

重积分的应用

😭终于到最后了

曲面的面积

看不懂，一点点都看不懂，直接记公式叭
求zx,zyz_x,z_yzx​,zy​,然后带入公式1+zx2+zy2\sqrt{1+z_x^2+z_y^2}1+zx2​+zy2​​
贴一道题

其实弄到还是看着底面投影进行积分，好难

质心

先求出来薄片的面积，然后对x和y进行积分(∬Dxdσ,∬Dydσ\iint\limits_{D}xd \sigma,\iint\limits_{D}yd \sigmaD∬​xdσ,D∬​ydσ)，如果题上给密度u(x,y)了，那就把密度函数也放到这俩被积函数里边
求出来的这两积分，分别除以面积就是质心的横纵坐标

转动惯量

直接上公式，如果是只有x，y的坐标轴，那就把z给去了，其他都一样

Ix=∭Ω(y2+z2)μ(x,y,z) dv,Iy=∭Ω(z2+x2)μ(x,y,z) dvIz=∭Ω(x2+y2)μ(x,y,z) dv,Io=∭Ω(x2+y2+z2)μ(x,y,z) dv\begin{align*} I_{x} &= \iiint_{\Omega} (y^{2} + z^{2}) \mu(x,y,z) \, \mathrm{d}v, & I_{y} &= \iiint_{\Omega} (z^{2} + x^{2}) \mu(x,y,z) \, \mathrm{d}v \\\\ I_{z} &= \iiint_{\Omega} (x^{2} + y^{2}) \mu(x,y,z) \, \mathrm{d}v, & I_{o} &= \iiint_{\Omega} (x^{2} + y^{2} + z^{2}) \mu(x,y,z) \, \mathrm{d}v \end{align*} Ix​Iz​​=∭Ω​(y2+z2)μ(x,y,z)dv,=∭Ω​(x2+y2)μ(x,y,z)dv,​Iy​Io​​=∭Ω​(z2+x2)μ(x,y,z)dv=∭Ω​(x2+y2+z2)μ(x,y,z)dv​

entry.title: 二重积分习题总结
entry.content:
type one：根据极限化积分


本质还是和之前的积分一样，传送门
提出来一个1m或者1n\frac{1}{m}或者\frac{1}{n}m1​或者n1​当dx或者dy，in或im变成x或ydx或者dy ，\frac{i}{n}或\frac{i}{m}变成x或ydx或者dy，ni​或mi​变成x或y
哎呀，其实都一样，就是一个变成了两个
跳过

type two：根据奇偶性简化运算


第一道
从-1到1，x的范围对称，所以看被积函数关于x的奇偶性，第一个项是偶函数，所以这一部分翻倍，第二项是奇函数，所以抵消

第二道
积分区域关于x、y轴对称
把被积函数展开，x2，4y2x^2，4y^2x2，4y2偶函数翻倍，4xy4xy4xy光看x是奇函数，所以抵消，就不用看y了，x和y就看一个，哪个起作用看哪个

type three：求带有积分的极限


这种类型不管长的多唬人都有两个东西
一个是等价无穷小替换或者泰勒展开，另一个是洛必达
先把分母无穷小替换了，然后洛必达
对于分母可以变成极坐标下的二重积分，θ可以直接算出来，后边变成了关于ρ的积分，直接根据这个技巧求导

type four：含自积分项的二元函数方程求解


可以想到后边那个二重积分的项就是一个常数，直接写成C
然后对f(x,y)=xy−Cf(x,y)=xy-Cf(x,y)=xy−C进行积分，算到最后就剩一个C是未知数
然后解方程就出来了

type five：积分区域关于y=x对称


唉😮‍💨，吃一堑长一堑的题型，总是想不起来这个特性
积分区域关于y=x对称的话，被积分函数的xy可以呼唤位置结果还不变，换之前的式子和换之后的式子相加刚好可以消掉

还有一道

可烦，课本上二重积分和三重积分是一章
接力题典上三重积分和曲线曲面积分是一章
总结都不好总结
而且二重积分的内容就这一点，五个题型反反复复出

entry.content:
Title: Threads of Conspiracy: When Worlds Collide

Main Idea: A tech scandal, environmental sabotage, and political corruption intertwine across multiple settings, revealing hidden connections through the lens of ordinary people caught in extraordinary chaos.

【The Glitch in the System】

In a sleek urban tech hub, engineer Mia stared at the console, her fingers flying to evaluate the erratic algorithm. “This isn’t just a glitch,” she muttered, noticing subtle code alterations that corresponded to a suspicious pattern. Her mentor had warned her: “One wrong variable could collide with the automation grid.” Suddenly, alarms emitted a harsh shriek—the entire building’s lights flickered, casting radiant beams through the glass structure. Security rushed to confine the breach, but Mia’s gut said this was plausible sabotage. She concealed a flash drive in her purse, determined to unfold the truth later.

【Jungle Secrets】

Meanwhile, in a tropical rainforest, biologist Leo encountered something grim. His conservation team found victims of illegal poaching—savage acts that sparked outrage. “They’re targeting endangered species,” he growled, soaking his boots in muddy water. A rustle in the bushes revealed a criminal gang. Leo evaded their grasp, but not before spotting a logo on their gear: the same enterprise Mia’s tech firm endorsed. Was this a coincidence? He tossed his satellite phone to a colleague, whispering, “Send this clue to the authorities—stat.”

【The Politician’s Downfall】

Downtown, prominent politician James Carter stood at a podium, delivering a fiery speech about abolishing corrupt stereotypes. His enthusiastic supporters cheered, unaware his aide had just betrayed him. By midnight, evidence leaked online: audio clips of James confessing to tax fraud, his voice barely audible over jazz trumpet music. News anchors remarked, “This scandal could render his career obsolete.” But who orchestrated the leak? A shadowy figure watched from a limousine, smirking—it was the CEO of Mia’s company.

【Art Heist Mysteries】

At a gallery showcasing masterpieces, curator Emma noticed something peculiar. A priceless painting had been replaced with a crude imitation. “This isn’t just theft,” she muttered, spotting negligible brushstroke differences. Security footage showed a suspicious figure lurking near the ceiling vents—the same tactic used in Mia’s tech breach. Emma deduced the thief left a clue: a biography page tucked under a vessel. The text was heavily redacted, except one phrase: “The circuit connects.”

【Campus Codebreakers】

On a campus buzzing with zeal, coding prodigy Dev labored over a turbine prototype. His team’s ambition? To liberate renewable energy from corporate greed. But during a demo, the machine emitted a burst of sparks. “We need to amend the circuit!” he yelled. A visiting investor offered a generous deal, but Dev’s gut said no. Later, he found a hidden file in the code—a blueprint matching Mia’s stolen tech. “They’re using us to shield their dirty work,” he realized, slamming his laptop shut.

【The Human Thread】

In a quiet suburb, single mom Nora knitted a scarf, her passion project to fund her daughter’s education. The radio hummed with news of chaos—cyberattacks, political meltdowns, environmental crises. But here, life was simple: cherishing bedtime stories, baking pies with organic ingredients, laughing at ironic sitcoms. As Nora glanced at her sleeping child, she whispered, “Whatever’s looming out there… we’ll thrive.” Sometimes, the most significant battles were fought not in boardrooms or jungles, but in quiet moments of genuine love.

Note: Some words (e.g., mortgage, pension, rhetoric) were omitted to preserve natural flow. Each section ties to a central theme of interconnected conflicts, with casual dialogue and relatable stakes.

entry.title: learn words from text2 in 2024
entry.content:
Text 2

Parenting tips obtained from hunter-gatherers in Africa may be the key to bringing up more contented children, researchers have suggested. The idea is based on studies of communities such as the Kung of Botswana, where each child is cared for by many adults. Kung children as young as four will help to look after younger ones and “baby-wearing”, in which infants are carried in slings, is considered the norm.

According to Dr Nikhil Chaudhary, an evolutionary anthropologist at Cambridge University, these practices, known as alloparenting, could lead to less anxiety for children and parents.

Dr Annie Swanepool, a child psychiatrist, believes that there are ways to incorporate them into western life. In Germany, one scheme has paired an old people’s home with a nursery. The residents help to look after the children, an arrangement akin to alloparenting. Another measure could be encouraging friendship between children in different school years to mirror the unsupervised mixed-age playgroups in hunter-gatherer communities.

In a paper published in the Journal of Child Psychology and Psychiatry, researchers said that the western nuclear family was a recent invention which broke with revolutionary history. This abrupt shift to an “intensive mothering narrative”, which suggests that mothers should manage childcare alone, was likely to have been harmful. “Such narratives can lead to maternal exhaustion and have dangerous consequences,” they wrote.

By contrast, in hunter-gatherer societies adults other than the parents can provide almost half of a child’s care. One previous study looked at the Efé people of the Democratic Republic of Congo. It found that infants had an average of 14 alloparents a day by the time they were 18 weeks old and were passed between caregivers eight times an hour.

Chaudhary said that parents now had less childcare support from family and social networks than during most of humans’ evolutionary history, but introducing additional caregivers could reduce stress and maternal depression, which could have a “knock-on” benefit to a child’s wellbeing. An infant born to a hunter-gatherer society could have more than ten caregivers—this contrasts starkly to nursery settings in the UK where regulations call for a ratio of one carer to four children aged two to three.

While hunter-gatherer children learnt from observation and imitation in mixed-age playgroups, researchers said that western “instructive teaching”, where pupils are asked to sit still, may contribute to conditions such as attention deficit hyperactivity disorder. Chaudhary said that Britain should explore the possibility that older siblings helping their parents “might also enhance their own social development”.

生词释义

  1. infant - n.

    • paraphrase：a very young child or baby
    • synonym：baby, newborn
    • example：When the mother carried the infant in a sling, the baby felt safe and could observe the surroundings easily.

  2. sling - n.

    • paraphrase：a cloth band used to carry babies
    • synonym：carrier, wrap
    • example：The mother tied her baby to her chest with a sling so she could work while keeping the child close.

  3. norm - n.

    • paraphrase：common practice or standard
    • synonym：standard, custom
    • example：In some cultures, sharing childcare duties is the norm, whereas in others it is rare.

  4. evolutionary - adj.

    • paraphrase：related to gradual development over time
    • synonym：developmental, progressive
    • example：Evolutionary studies show that humans naturally relied on group parenting for survival.

  5. revolutionary - adj.

    • paraphrase：completely new and different from the past
    • synonym：radical, groundbreaking
    • example：The nuclear family model was a revolutionary change that disrupted ancient childcare patterns.

  6. anthropologist - n.

    • paraphrase：a person who studies human societies
    • synonym：researcher, ethnologist
    • example：The anthropologist observed that hunter-gatherer children learn through imitation rather than formal lessons.

  7. incorporate - v.

    • paraphrase：to include something as part of a system
    • synonym：integrate, adopt
    • example：Schools could incorporate mixed-age playgroups if they want to mirror traditional learning methods.

  8. scheme - n.

    • paraphrase：an organized plan or project
    • synonym：program, initiative
    • example：The government introduced a new scheme where schools and hospitals work together to improve community health.

  9. pair - v.

    • paraphrase：to connect two things together
    • synonym：match, combine
    • example：Researchers suggested we pair retirement homes with nurseries so elders can interact with children.

  10. nursery - n.

    • paraphrase：a place where young children are cared for
    • synonym：daycare, kindergarten
    • example：At the nursery, toddlers play with toys while caregivers monitor their activities.

  11. akin - adj.

    • paraphrase：similar to something
    • synonym：similar, comparable
    • example：The community project is akin to traditional alloparenting because multiple adults care for each child.

  12. unsupervised - adj.

    • paraphrase：without adult watching
    • synonym：unmonitored, free
    • example：Children in mixed-age groups often play unsupervised, which helps them develop problem-solving skills.

  13. mirror - v.

    • paraphrase：to copy or reflect
    • synonym：imitate, replicate
    • example：Modern schools could mirror hunter-gatherer communities by allowing children to learn through exploration.

  14. abrupt - adj.

    • paraphrase：sudden and unexpected
    • synonym：sharp, hurried
    • example：The abrupt shift to single-parent childcare left many mothers feeling overwhelmed.

  15. narrative - n.

    • paraphrase：a story or belief system
    • synonym：storyline, account
    • example：The cultural narrative that mothers must handle childcare alone increases stress levels.

  16. maternal - adj.

    • paraphrase：related to motherhood
    • synonym：motherly, parental
    • example：Maternal exhaustion often occurs when mothers lack support from extended family.

  17. exhaustion - n.

    • paraphrase：extreme tiredness
    • synonym：fatigue, burnout
    • example：Prolonged exhaustion can harm both physical health and emotional wellbeing.

  18. knock-on - adj.

    • paraphrase：having a chain effect
    • synonym：ripple, cascading
    • example：Reducing maternal stress has a knock-on benefit because happier parents raise more confident children.

  19. starkly - adv.

    • paraphrase：in a clearly different way
    • synonym：sharply, distinctly
    • example：Hunter-gatherer childcare contrasts starkly with modern systems that limit caregiver numbers.

  20. instructive - adj.

    • paraphrase：providing knowledge through direct teaching
    • synonym：educational, informative
    • example：While instructive lessons are common in schools, play-based learning may be more natural for children.

  21. pupil - n.

    • paraphrase：a student in school
    • synonym：student, learner
    • example：When pupils are forced to sit still for hours, they may develop attention difficulties.

  22. hyperactivity - n.

    • paraphrase：excessive physical movement
    • synonym：restlessness, fidgeting
    • example：Some experts believe that hyperactivity in children arises from unnatural learning environments.

  23. deficit - n.

    • paraphrase：lack of something necessary
    • synonym：shortage, insufficiency
    • example：Attention deficit disorders might be linked to limited opportunities for free play.

  24. sibling - n.

    • paraphrase：a brother or sister
    • synonym：brother/sister, kin
    • example：Older siblings who help care for younger ones often develop stronger leadership skills.

entry.title: 理解积分
entry.content:
理解三重积分的方式

一重积分可以用面积理解，二重积分可以用体积理解，三重积分显然无法用这种方法理解，我如何理解三重积分

  1. 物理量的总和：当被积函数表示密度（如质量密度、电荷密度）时，三重积分的结果是该物理量在三维区域内的总量。例如，物体的总质量可通过积分密度函数得到。

  2. 概率与统计：若被积函数是概率密度函数，三重积分可计算三维区域内事件发生的概率。

  3. 几何测度：当被积函数恒为1时，三重积分的结果即为区域的体积，此时与几何直观一致。

  4. 数学抽象：作为多维空间中的累积操作，三重积分可视为在三个独立方向上的加权求和，无需依赖四维几何直观，而是通过逐次积分或坐标变换进行计算。

  5. 物理定律应用：如高斯定理中，三重积分用于计算场源（如电荷总量），与曲面积分结合揭示物理规律。

使用质量密度理解三重积分

假设有一个三维物体，其质量密度随位置变化，我们可以用三重积分求出它的总质量。这个例子将帮助你建立对三重积分的直观理解。

例子：计算一个长方体的总质量

问题设定：
假设有一个长方体物体，占据空间区域：

  • xxx 方向范围：0≤x≤20 \leq x \leq 20≤x≤2
  • yyy 方向范围：0≤y≤10 \leq y \leq 10≤y≤1
  • zzz 方向范围：0≤z≤10 \leq z \leq 10≤z≤1

它的质量密度函数为：

ρ(x,y,z)=3x(单位：kg/m3)\rho(x, y, z) = 3x \quad (\text{单位：kg/m}^3) ρ(x,y,z)=3x(单位：kg/m3)

目标：用三重积分计算这个物体的总质量。

步骤说明

  1. 物理意义：
    每个点的质量密度为 ρ(x,y,z)=3x\rho(x, y, z) = 3xρ(x,y,z)=3x，即密度随着 xxx 的增大而线性增加（例如，在 x=0x=0x=0 处密度为0，在 x=2x=2x=2 处密度为6 kg/m³）。
    总质量 = 所有点的质量密度在三维空间上的累积。

  2. 三重积分的作用：
    总质量可以表示为：

    质量=∭长方体ρ(x,y,z)dV\text{质量} = \iiint_{\text{长方体}} \rho(x, y, z) dV 质量=∭长方体​ρ(x,y,z)dV

    其中 dV=dxdydzdV = dx dy dzdV=dxdydz 是三维体积微元。

直观理解

  1. 密度变化的体现：
  • 在 x=0x=0x=0 处密度为0，因此这一侧对质量的贡献为0。
  • 在 x=2x=2x=2 处密度最大（6 kg/m³），这一侧贡献了更多质量。
  • 积分结果（6 kg）反映了密度在空间中的加权累积。

  1. 对比均匀密度：
    如果密度是均匀的（例如 ρ=3kg/m3\rho = 3 \text{kg/m}^3ρ=3kg/m3），总质量为：

    ρ×体积=3×(2⋅1⋅1)=6kg\rho \times \text{体积} = 3 \times (2 \cdot 1 \cdot 1) = 6 \text{kg} ρ×体积=3×(2⋅1⋅1)=6kg

    但在这个例子中，尽管密度不均匀，总质量巧合地相同——这是因为密度函数 ρ(x)=3x\rho(x) = 3xρ(x)=3x 在 xxx 方向上的“平均密度”正好是3 kg/m³。

  2. 推广到复杂情况：

  • 如果密度函数更复杂（例如 ρ(x,y,z)=x2+yz\rho(x, y, z) = x^2 + yzρ(x,y,z)=x2+yz），三重积分依然可以计算总质量，只是步骤更繁琐。
  • 若物体形状不规则（如球体、圆柱体），可以用柱坐标或球坐标简化积分。

三重积分的核心思想

  • 三维空间的累积：将空间分解为无数个微小体积 dVdVdV，每个微元的质量为 ρdV\rho dVρdV，再将这些微元的质量“加总”。
  • 实际应用场景：
  • 计算质量、电荷量等物理量的总和。
  • 求解质心、转动惯量等物理属性（需加入位置权重，如 xρdVx\rho dVxρdV）。

对于二重积分除了使用体积去理解，还可以使用什么方法理解

二重积分除了用体积（曲顶柱体的体积）来理解外，还可以从以下角度建立直观理解，这些方法能更广泛地体现其实际意义和应用场景：

1. 物理量的总和：密度与质量

  • 核心思想：若被积函数表示某种密度（如质量密度、电荷密度、人口密度），二重积分的结果是该物理量在二维区域内的总量。
  • 例子：
    一块薄板在区域 DDD 上的质量密度为 ρ(x,y)\rho(x, y)ρ(x,y)，总质量为：

    质量=∬Dρ(x,y)dA\text{质量} = \iint_D \rho(x, y) dA 质量=∬D​ρ(x,y)dA

    ◦ 若 ρ(x,y)=2x+y\rho(x, y) = 2x + yρ(x,y)=2x+y（密度随位置变化），积分结果即为薄板的总质量。

2. 概率论：联合概率分布

  • 核心思想：若被积函数是联合概率密度函数 f(x,y)f(x, y)f(x,y)，二重积分可计算事件在区域 DDD 内发生的概率。
  • 例子：
    两个随机变量 XXX 和 YYY 的联合概率密度为 f(x,y)f(x, y)f(x,y)，则事件 (X,Y)∈D(X, Y) \in D(X,Y)∈D 的概率为：

    P=∬Df(x,y)dxdyP = \iint_D f(x, y) dx dy P=∬D​f(x,y)dxdy

    ◦ 例如，计算 XXX 和 YYY 均落在区间 [0,1][0,1][0,1]内的概率。

3. 几何量：面积、质心与转动惯量

  • 面积：当被积函数为 111 时，二重积分结果为区域的面积：

    面积=∬D1dA\text{面积} = \iint_D 1 dA 面积=∬D​1dA

我去，我理解了!!!二重积分求曲面面积
∬Dxy1+(∂z∂x)2+(∂z∂y)2dxdy\iint\limits_{D_{xy}} \sqrt{1 + \left(\frac{\partial z}{\partial x}\right)^2 + \left(\frac{\partial z}{\partial y}\right)^2} dxdyDxy​∬​1+(∂x∂z​)2+(∂y∂z​)2​dxdy
牢记住一句话，二重积分是平面区域上某个物理量的累加
这里的dxdy这里的dxdy这里的dxdy是一个平面，而且是贴着坐标面的平面
然后1+(∂z∂x)2+(∂z∂y)2\sqrt{1 + \left(\frac{\partial z}{\partial x}\right)^2 + \left(\frac{\partial z}{\partial y}\right)^2}1+(∂x∂z​)2+(∂y∂z​)2​这个式子就相当于一个缩放因子，每一小块区域对应不同的缩放，这个式子的意思就是把每一块经过缩放后的dxdydxdydxdy这一小块平面相加起来就是曲面的面积
至于缩放因子为啥是这样式的，我嚼不碎，哎呀，起码把这个整体嚼碎了一点，剩下的学了几何再理解

  • 质心坐标：
    质心 (xˉ,yˉ)(\bar{x}, \bar{y})(xˉ,yˉ​) 通过加权积分计算：

    xˉ=1质量∬Dxρ(x,y)dA,yˉ=1质量∬Dyρ(x,y)dA\bar{x} = \frac{1}{\text{质量}} \iint_D x \rho(x, y) dA, \quad \bar{y} = \frac{1}{\text{质量}} \iint_D y \rho(x, y) dA xˉ=质量1​∬D​xρ(x,y)dA,yˉ​=质量1​∬D​yρ(x,y)dA

如何理解这个公式以及加权这个概念
先从一维理解，从杠杆原理来说，一个平衡的杠杆，满足的等式是：m1x1=m2x2m_1x_1=m_2x_2m1​x1​=m2​x2​,左边的砝码乘以左边的力矩=右边的砝码乘以右边的力矩
当然，这是知道了质心（平衡点）的前提下这样算的，现在假装不知道质心，以左边的砝码位置做参考
左边的砝码重m1，x1=0m_1，x_1=0m1​，x1​=0，右边的砝码重m2,x2m_2,x_2m2​,x2​，质心(平衡点)的坐标就是x=m1x1+m2x2m1+m2x=\frac{m_1x_1+m_2x_2}{m_1+m_2}x=m1​+m2​m1​x1​+m2​x2​​，这里的距离x就是权重
然后推广到二维，用一个长方形举例，长方形上有可多和x轴平行的跷跷板，和平行于y轴的跷跷板，从左下角建系，质心x的坐标就是平行于x轴的跷跷板上的砝码乘上各自的距离最后再除以砝码总重，质心y的坐标就是平行于y轴的跷跷板上的砝码乘上各自的距离最后再除以砝码总重
然后再看质心 (xˉ,yˉ)(\bar{x}, \bar{y})(xˉ,yˉ​)的计算公式，公式有一个ρ，说明图形质量不均匀，在这一点的密度ρ乘以这一点的面积（我猜A应该是area的意思）=质量m，所有m和对应的距离x累积，再除以总质量就是质心的x坐标

  • 转动惯量：
    物体绕轴的转动惯量为：

    I=∬Dr2ρ(x,y)dAI = \iint_D r^2 \rho(x, y) dA I=∬D​r2ρ(x,y)dA

    其中 rrr 是点到旋转轴的距离。

    理解了上边的ρdA=mρdA=mρdA=m，这个公式就好理解了，惯就是惯性的意思，既然是惯性肯定和质量有关，玩过棍子的都知道，越长的棍子耍起来越吃力，惯性越大，这就是距离对外围质量的放大作用，r2r^2r2就是放大因子，为啥取平方，旋转的几何本质​​，线速度 v 随半径 r 线性增加，而动能依赖速度平方，导致 r2 的放大效应

4. 工程应用：流量与能量

  • 流量计算：向量场 F(x,y)\mathbf{F}(x, y)F(x,y) 通过区域 DDD 的流量可表示为：

    流量=∬DF⋅ndA\text{流量} = \iint_D \mathbf{F} \cdot \mathbf{n} dA 流量=∬D​F⋅ndA

    其中n\mathbf{n}n是单位法向量（需结合向量积分理解）。

    高中有个公式是磁通量Φ=BSΦ=BSΦ=BS，也就是垂直于平面的有效磁通量乘以平面面积
    这个公式流量=∬DF⋅ndA\text{流量} = \iint_D \mathbf{F} \cdot \mathbf{n} dA流量=∬D​F⋅ndA也是这样理解，A是area，也就是面积，F⋅n就是向量场F在平面法向量上的投影，点乘就是cos运算叭
    所以这个公式的意义就是把平面分成了可多小平面，求每个垂直于平面的有效向量场乘以小平面面积，然后把所有的流量加起来

  • 总能量或功率：
    若 f(x,y)f(x, y)f(x,y) 表示区域 DDD 上每点的能量密度，总能量为：

    E=∬Df(x,y)dAE = \iint_D f(x, y) dA E=∬D​f(x,y)dA

二重积分的本质

其意义取决于被积函数的物理或几何解释。通过选择不同的被积函数和区域，它可以表示：

  • 体积（当被积函数为高度 z=f(x,y)z = f(x, y)z=f(x,y)），
  • 质量、电荷等物理总量，
  • 概率、统计量，
  • 几何属性（如质心、转动惯量），
  • 工程中的流量、能量等。

二重积分的核心是 对二维区域上分布的某种量进行累积求和，
三重积分的作用是 对三维空间中分布的某种量进行累积求和。

对曲线积分的理解

第一类曲线积分（标量场）

∫Lf(x,y)ds=∫αβf[φ(t),ψ(t)]φ′2(t)+ψ′2(t)dt(α<β)\int_{L} f(x,y) \mathrm{d}s = \int_{\alpha}^{\beta} f\left[\varphi(t),\psi(t)\right] \sqrt{\varphi'^{2}(t) + \psi'^{2}(t)} \mathrm{d}t \quad (\alpha < \beta) ∫L​f(x,y)ds=∫αβ​f[φ(t),ψ(t)]φ′2(t)+ψ′2(t)​dt(α<β)

从物理上理解，等式右边的定积分可以拆解为两个关键部分，分别对应物理量的空间分布和曲线的几何特性。

f(φ(t),ψ(t))⏟物理量分布⋅φ′2(t)+ψ′2(t)⏟几何修正项 dt\underbrace{f\big(\varphi(t), \psi(t)\big)}_{\text{物理量分布}} \cdot \underbrace{\sqrt{\varphi'^{2}(t) + \psi'^{2}(t)}}_{\text{几何修正项}} \, dt 物理量分布f(φ(t),ψ(t))​​⋅几何修正项φ′2(t)+ψ′2(t)​​​dt

1. 物理量分布：f(φ(t),ψ(t))f(\varphi(t), \psi(t))f(φ(t),ψ(t))

  • 意义：金属丝在参数 ttt 对应位置 (φ(t),ψ(t))(\varphi(t), \psi(t))(φ(t),ψ(t)) 处的线密度。
  • 作用：给出金属丝上每一点的密度信息。例如，若 f(x,y)=2xf(x, y) = 2xf(x,y)=2x，则靠近 xxx 轴正方向的区域密度更大。

2. 几何修正项：φ′2(t)+ψ′2(t)\sqrt{\varphi'^2(t) + \psi'^2(t)}φ′2(t)+ψ′2(t)​

  • 意义：参数 ttt 变化时，金属丝的 瞬时速率（即弧长微元 dsdsds 与参数微元 dtdtdt 的比值）：

dsdt=(dxdt)2+(dydt)2=φ′2(t)+ψ′2(t) \frac{ds}{dt} = \sqrt{\left(\frac{dx}{dt}\right)^2 + \left(\frac{dy}{dt}\right)^2} = \sqrt{\varphi'^2(t) + \psi'^2(t)} dtds​=(dtdx​)2+(dtdy​)2​=φ′2(t)+ψ′2(t)​

  • 作用：将参数 ttt 的积分转换为实际弧长 sss 的积分。因为金属丝可能“疏密不均”地参数化（例如 ttt 变化快时，ds/dtds/dtds/dt 大），需通过此因子修正。

3. 积分结果：总质量

  • 物理过程：
    将金属丝沿参数 ttt 切割为无数小段，每段的质量为：

质量微元=线密度×弧长微元=f(φ(t),ψ(t))⋅ds=f(φ(t),ψ(t))⋅φ′2(t)+ψ′2(t)dt \text{质量微元} = \text{线密度} \times \text{弧长微元} = f(\varphi(t), \psi(t)) \cdot ds = f(\varphi(t), \psi(t)) \cdot \sqrt{\varphi'^2(t) + \psi'^2(t)} dt 质量微元=线密度×弧长微元=f(φ(t),ψ(t))⋅ds=f(φ(t),ψ(t))⋅φ′2(t)+ψ′2(t)​dt

积分将所有微元质量累加，得到总质量：

总质量=∫αβf(φ(t),ψ(t))φ′2(t)+ψ′2(t)dt \text{总质量} = \int_{\alpha}^{\beta} f(\varphi(t), \psi(t)) \sqrt{\varphi'^2(t) + \psi'^2(t)} dt 总质量=∫αβ​f(φ(t),ψ(t))φ′2(t)+ψ′2(t)​dt

一句话答案：
等式右边的定积分从物理上可理解为 沿参数化曲线的实际路径，对物理量分布进行累积求和，其中被积函数的几何修正项（根号部分）将参数变化率转换为实际弧长微元，确保积分结果与曲线形状匹配。

第二类曲线积分(向量场)

W=∫LPdx+QdyW = \int_L P dx + Q dy W=∫L​Pdx+Qdy

  • Pdx：力F在 x 方向的分量 P 乘以微小位移 dx，即 x 方向的微功。
  • Qdy：力F在 y 方向的分量 Q 乘以微小位移 dy，即 y 方向的微功。
  • ​​总功​​：两者相加 Pdx+Qdy 是力的总微功，积分后得到沿曲线的总功。

如何理解这一类曲线积分的积分值和积分路径有关？

头开始我想的是重力场，根本无法理解，高度一定不管我从哪里出发消耗的能量都一样，显然重力场无法适用这种理解，重力场是保守场，也就是场内没有内在的“旋转”或耗散机制，也没有奇点干扰（在这一点处，曲率突变，我去，和广义相对论对上了，通透）
非保守场那就是和保守场相反了
这个路径有关就是应该在非保守场里边理解，比如说漩涡
用赫尔辛根默斯肯那个例子理解，他们开着船可以从外边开到里边，但是用这点功不可能从里边开到外边

从物理意义理解曲线积分与路径无关的条件

∂P∂y=∂Q∂x\frac{\partial P}{\partial y} = \frac{\partial Q}{\partial x} ∂y∂P​=∂x∂Q​

∂\partial∂读partial
其实这个式子应该变换一下看∂P∂y−∂Q∂x=0\frac{\partial P}{\partial y} - \frac{\partial Q}{\partial x}=0∂y∂P​−∂x∂Q​=0，等号前边是旋度，没错，就是曲面积分斯托克斯公式那里的旋度，只不过这个是二维的，那个是三维的
旋度可以粗略地理解成漩涡，因为有“漩涡”的存在所以造成了场在空间分部不平坦
如果旋度等于零，说明这个场是平坦的保守场，也就可以用重力场那一套来理解为什么积分结果与积分路径无关了

一类、二类曲线积分的数学与物理区别

1. 数学形式的区别

类型 第一类曲线积分（对弧长的积分） 第二类曲线积分（对坐标的积分）
积分符号 ∫Cf(x,y)ds\int_C f(x,y) ds∫C​f(x,y)ds ∫CPdx+Qdy\int_C P dx + Q dy∫C​Pdx+Qdy
被积函数 标量函数 f(x,y)f(x,y)f(x,y) 向量场分量 P(x,y)P(x,y)P(x,y)、Q(x,y)Q(x,y)Q(x,y)
积分微元 弧长微元 dsdsds 坐标微元 dxdxdx、dydydy
参数化形式 ∫abf(r(t))r′(t) dt\int_a^b f(\mathbf{r}(t)) \mathbf{r}'(t)\ dt∫ab​f(r(t))r′(t) dt ∫ab[Pdxdt+Qdydt]dt\int_a^b \left[ P \frac{dx}{dt} + Q \frac{dy}{dt} \right] dt∫ab​[Pdtdx​+Qdtdy​]dt
方向性 与曲线方向无关（无方向性） 与曲线方向相关（有方向性）

2. 物理意义的区别

第一类曲线积分
  • 核心意义：计算 标量场沿曲线的累积量。
  • 典型应用：
    • 曲线型物体的质量（fff 为线密度）。
    • 曲线的长度（f=1f = 1f=1 时，∫Cds=弧长\int_C ds = \text{弧长}∫C​ds=弧长）。
    • 标量场（如温度、高度）沿曲线的平均值。
第二类曲线积分
  • 核心意义：计算 向量场沿曲线的做功或通量。
  • 典型应用：
    • 做功问题：力场 F=(P,Q)\mathbf{F} = (P, Q)F=(P,Q) 沿曲线移动质点做的功（W=∫CF⋅drW = \int_C \mathbf{F} \cdot d\mathbf{r}W=∫C​F⋅dr）。
    • 流量问题：流体通过曲线的流量（需结合法向量）。

对曲面积分的理解

第一类曲面积分(标量场)

第一类曲面积分的理解和第一类曲线积分差不多，只不过把线段长换成了面积
被积函数还是可以看成密度这种物理量的分布
几何修正项的套路也一样
积分结果是曲面的总质量

我去！！！！！
这个几何修正项可以用二重积分里的求面积那里去理解，传送门

∬∑f(x,y,z)dS=∬Dxyf[x,y,z(x,y)]1+zx2(x,y)+zy2(x,y)dxdy\iint_{\sum} f(x,y,z) dS = \iint_{D_{xy}} f[x,y,z(x,y)] \sqrt{1 + z_{x}^{2}(x,y) + z_{y}^{2}(x,y)} dxdy ∬∑​f(x,y,z)dS=∬Dxy​​f[x,y,z(x,y)]1+zx2​(x,y)+zy2​(x,y)​dxdy

1+zx2(x,y)+zy2(x,y)\sqrt{1+z_{x}^{2}(x,y)+z_{y}^{2}(x,y)}1+zx2​(x,y)+zy2​(x,y)​是缩放因子，
dxdydxdydxdy是坐标面（xoy）上的小面积
小面积缩放到原本的曲面上，为面积S
f[x,y,z(x,y)]是密度函数ρ
所以积分可以理解为m=ρSm=ρSm=ρS

∬Σf(x,y,z)dS⏟质量 m=∬Dxyf[x,y,z(x,y)]⏟密度 ρ1+zx2(x,y)+zy2(x,y)dxdy⏟面积 S\iint_{\Sigma} \underbrace{f(x, y, z) d S}_{\text {质量 } m}=\iint_{D_{x y}} \underbrace{f[x, y, z(x, y)]}_{\text {密度 } \rho} \underbrace{\sqrt{1+z_{x}^{2}(x, y)+z_{y}^{2}(x, y)} d x d y}_{\text {面积 } S} ∬Σ​质量 mf(x,y,z)dS​​=∬Dxy​​密度 ρf[x,y,z(x,y)]​​面积 S1+zx2​(x,y)+zy2​(x,y)​dxdy​​

第二类曲面积分(向量场)

第二类曲面积分是对向量场穿过定向曲面的通量（或流量）的积分。其数学表达式为：

∬SF⋅ndS\iint_S \mathbf{F} \cdot \mathbf{n} dS ∬S​F⋅ndS

其中，F=Pi+Qj+Rk\mathbf{F} = P\mathbf{i} + Q\mathbf{j} + R\mathbf{k}F=Pi+Qj+Rk 是一个向量场，ndS\mathbf{n} dSndS 是这一点小平面与法向量的乘积，可以理解为曲面S在X、Y、Z方向上的有效面积

核心要点：

  1. 积分对象：向量场沿曲面法线方向的分量。
    第二类曲面积分计算的是向量场 F\mathbf{F}F 在曲面每个点处与法向量 n\mathbf{n}n 的点乘，再对整个曲面求和，结果表示向量场穿过曲面的总通量。
  2. 物理意义：
    若 F\mathbf{F}F 表示流速场，积分结果为通过曲面的总流量；若为电场或磁场，则积分表示电通量或磁通量。

entry.title: 确定化与最小化
entry.content:
确定化
用画表法
第一步：第一列写出所有的状态，第一行写出所有的弧名

状态应该不是所有节点的排列组合，要不先把所有单个节点的状态写出来，然后单个节点推出来新的状态之后再把这个新状态写到第一列

第二步：给左边第一列的所有状态编号，0、1、2、……，然后把表中的所有状态用编号代替
第三步：根据这个编号得出的新表画出确定化的图

什么是终态终态：原图上的终态，和包含所有节点的状态

举个例子

最小化
记住一句话，分组后的元素，经过a弧到达的状态在同一组中，经过b弧到达的状态也在同一组中（这两个组不一定相同）
根据上一个得出的确定化图写
第一步：分组，把非终态分成一组，把终态分成一组
对两个组分别用相同的方法进行处理，所以光以非终态组为例说明
第二步：写出每一个元素通过a弧的状态
第三步：看是否在同一组中，是的话直接看通过b弧的状态，不是的话，把不同的状态按相同的组进行分类
第四步：看分了之后的组通过b弧的状态，这些状态在同一个组中的话，那么这些状态就可以合并

entry.content:
单词释义

  1. governor - n.

    • paraphrase：a person who controls a region or organization

    • synonym：leader, ruler

    • example：Although the governor proposed new policies, many citizens disagreed because they felt the changes were unfair.

  2. acute - adj.

    • paraphrase：very serious or severe

    • synonym：intense, sharp

    • example：The doctor said the pain was acute, so she prescribed medicine which would help reduce it quickly.

  3. organism - n.

    • paraphrase：a living thing, like a plant or animal

    • synonym：creature, being

    • example：Scientists study tiny organisms that live in water to understand how they survive whereas larger animals need more resources.

  4. tragedy - n.

    • paraphrase：a very sad event or disaster

    • synonym：disaster, misfortune

    • example：The earthquake was a tragedy that affected thousands, but the community rebuilt what was destroyed over time.

  5. spouse - n.

    • paraphrase：a husband or wife

    • synonym：partner, mate

    • example：When my spouse travels for work, I take care of the kids unless my parents can help.

  6. outlook - n.

    • paraphrase：a person’s way of thinking about something

    • synonym：perspective, attitude

    • example：Her outlook on life is positive, although she faces challenges that would discourage others.

  7. invoke - v.

    • paraphrase：to call on something for help or support

    • synonym：summon, cite

    • example：The lawyer invoked a law which protects workers’ rights, whereas the company argued it didn’t apply.

  8. turbulent - adj.

    • paraphrase：full of conflict or disorder

    • synonym：chaotic, unstable

    • example：The flight was turbulent because of the storm, so the pilot changed course where the weather was calmer.

  9. interference - n.

    • paraphrase：unwanted involvement that disrupts

    • synonym：disruption, meddling

    • example：The Wi-Fi signal was weak due to interference from other devices, unless we moved closer to the router.

  10. globe - n.

  • paraphrase：the Earth or a round object representing it

  • synonym：planet, sphere

  • example：Climate change affects the entire globe, which is why countries must work together to find solutions.

  1. psychiatry - n.

  • synonym：therapy, mental health

  • example：Psychiatry helps people who struggle with anxiety, although some prefer alternative treatments like meditation.

  1. whirl - v.

  • paraphrase：to spin or move quickly in circles

  • synonym：spin, twirl

  • example：The leaves whirled in the wind when the storm started, whereas the heavier branches stayed still.

  1. employment - n.

  • paraphrase：having a job or work

  • synonym：job, occupation

  • example：Employment rates improved after the factory opened, which provided jobs for many locals.

  1. rational - adj.

  • example：His decision was rational because he weighed all the options before choosing.

  1. welfare - n.

  • paraphrase：the health and happiness of people

  • synonym：well-being, safety

  • example：The government increased welfare programs so that families in need could get help if they qualified.

  1. symptom - n.

  • paraphrase：a sign of illness or a problem

  • synonym：sign, indicator

  • example：A fever is a symptom of infection, although not all infections cause one.

  1. currency - n.

  • paraphrase：the money used in a country

  • synonym：money, cash

  • example：The euro is the currency used in France, whereas Japan uses the yen.

  1. insight - n.

  • paraphrase：a deep understanding of something

  • synonym：understanding, wisdom

  • example：Her insight into the problem helped solve it, which surprised everyone.

  1. defence - n.

  • paraphrase：protection against harm or attack

  • synonym：protection, security

  • example：The army strengthened its defence because tensions were rising in the region.

  1. capable - adj.

  • paraphrase：able to do something well

  • synonym：competent, skilled

  • example：She is capable of fixing the computer, unless the problem is too complex.

  1. acquisition - n.

  • paraphrase：the act of gaining something

  • synonym：purchase, obtainment

  • example：The company’s acquisition of the smaller firm was successful, although some employees were laid off.

  1. classify - v.

  • paraphrase：to sort things into groups

  • synonym：categorize, organize

  • example：Scientists classify animals based on their traits, which helps in studying them.

  1. allowance - n.

  • paraphrase：money given regularly for a purpose

  • synonym：stipend, budget

  • example：Parents give their kids an allowance so they can learn how to manage money.

  1. duplicity - n.

  • paraphrase：dishonest behavior that deceives

  • synonym：deceit, deception

  • example：His duplicity was revealed when the truth came out, whereas others had trusted him completely.

  1. superb - adj.

  • paraphrase：excellent or of very high quality

  • synonym：excellent, outstanding

  • example：The concert was superb because the musicians played perfectly.

  1. considerate - adj.

  • paraphrase：thoughtful of others’ feelings

  • synonym：kind, thoughtful

  • example：He is considerate, so he always asks if others need help before acting.

  1. coherent - adj.

  • paraphrase：clear and logical

  • synonym：logical, consistent

  • example：Her argument was coherent, which made it easy to follow her reasoning.

  1. spot - n.

  • paraphrase：a small mark or place

  • synonym：mark, stain

  1. elect - v.

  • paraphrase：to choose someone by voting

  • synonym：select, vote for

  • example：Citizens will elect a new mayor unless the election is postponed.

  • synonym：ask, seek advice

  • synonym：vanished, dead

  • example：Dinosaurs are extinct, although scientists study their fossils to learn about them.

  1. premier - adj.

  • paraphrase：first in importance or rank

  • synonym：leading, top

  • example：The premier university in the country attracts students from all over the world.

  1. composition - n.

  • paraphrase：the way something is made or written

  • synonym：structure, makeup

  • example：The composition of the painting was balanced, which made it pleasing to look at.

  1. circumstance - n.

  • synonym：greedy, self-centered

  • synonym：section, branch

  • example：The IT department fixed the computers when they crashed, which prevented delays.

  1. rival - n.

  • synonym：competitor, opponent

  • example：The two companies are rivals, although they sometimes collaborate on projects.

  • synonym：impartial, unbiased

entry.title: words-ninth-day
entry.content:
单词释义

  1. mature - adj./v.

    • paraphrase：fully grown or developed

    • synonym：grown, ripe, adult

    • example：Although the fruit looks ripe, it needs more time to mature before we can eat it.

  2. imminent - adj.

    • paraphrase：about to happen very soon

    • synonym：approaching, nearing

    • example：The storm clouds suggest rain is imminent, so we should hurry home unless we want to get wet.

  3. convention - n.

    • paraphrase：a formal meeting or accepted way of doing things

    • synonym：conference, custom

    • example：At the tech convention, which lasted three days, experts discussed AI trends whereas beginners attended workshops.

  4. portrait - n.

    • paraphrase：a painting or photo of a person

    • synonym：picture, image

    • example：She painted a portrait that captured his smile, which reminded her of their childhood together.

  5. suppress - v.

    • paraphrase：to stop by force or control

    • synonym：restrain, quell

    • example：The government tried to suppress the protest, but it grew larger when news spread online.

  6. excess - n./adj.

    • paraphrase：more than what is needed

    • synonym：surplus, extra

    • example：If you eat in excess, you might gain weight unless you exercise regularly.

  7. religious - adj.

    • paraphrase：related to religion or very careful

    • synonym：devout, faithful

    • example：She follows her routine with religious dedication, whereas her brother prefers spontaneity.

  8. sanction - n./v.

    • paraphrase：official permission or punishment

    • synonym：approval, penalty

    • example：The UN imposed sanctions, which angered the country’s leaders although they claimed innocence.

  9. field - n./v.

    • paraphrase：an area of land or a subject of study

    • synonym：domain, meadow

    • example：He works in the medical field, where research is advancing rapidly because of new technology.

  10. acclaim - n./v.

    • paraphrase：public praise

    • synonym：praise, applause

    • example：The film received critical acclaim when it premiered, even though its budget was small.

  11. sow - v.

    • paraphrase：to plant seeds

    • synonym：plant, scatter

    • example：Farmers sow crops in spring so that they can harvest them before winter arrives.

  12. exotic - adj.

    • paraphrase：unusual and from a distant place

    • synonym：foreign, unusual

    • example：She loves exotic fruits, whereas her brother prefers local apples and oranges.

  13. legitimate - adj.

    • paraphrase：legal or reasonable

    • synonym：valid, lawful

    • example：Although his request seemed odd, it was legitimate because he followed the rules.

  14. likewise - adv.

    • paraphrase：in the same way

    • synonym：similarly, also

    • example：She enjoys hiking; likewise, her brother loves outdoor activities.

  15. suspicion - n.

    • paraphrase：a feeling that something is wrong

    • synonym：doubt, mistrust

    • example：He had a suspicion that the deal was too good, which turned out to be true.

  16. agitate - v.

    • paraphrase：to make someone worried or to stir

    • synonym：disturb, upset

    • example：The loud noise agitated the dog, so it barked until the sound stopped.

  17. tease - v.

    • paraphrase：to make fun of or annoy playfully

    • synonym：mock, joke

    • example：She teased her brother about his haircut, but she stopped when he got upset.

  18. sufficient - adj.

    • paraphrase：enough for a purpose

    • synonym：adequate, enough

    • example：Unless you have sufficient evidence, the court won’t accept your claim.

  19. overlap - v./n.

    • paraphrase：to partly cover or share features

    • synonym：intersect, coincide

    • example：Their work schedules overlap, which makes it hard to meet for lunch.

  20. swell - v./n.

    • paraphrase：to become larger or a rise

    • synonym：expand, increase

    • example：Her ankle began to swell after she twisted it, so she applied ice.

  21. steer - v.

    • paraphrase：to guide or control direction

    • synonym：direct, navigate

    • example：He steered the conversation away from politics because it caused arguments.

  22. controversy - n.

    • paraphrase：public disagreement

    • synonym：dispute, debate

    • example：The new law sparked controversy, whereas supporters argued it was necessary.

  23. ruling - n.

    • paraphrase：an official decision

    • synonym：verdict, judgment

    • example：The court’s ruling was fair, although some people still disagreed.

  24. tow - v./n.

    • paraphrase：to pull with a rope or chain

    • synonym：drag, haul

    • example：The truck towed the broken car to the garage, where mechanics could fix it.

  25. pride - n.

    • paraphrase：a feeling of satisfaction

    • synonym：dignity, self-respect

    • example：She felt pride when she finished the project, which took months of hard work.

entry.title: word-tenth-day
entry.content:
单词释义

  1. reverse - v./n./adj.

    • paraphrase：to go backward or change to the opposite

    • synonym：undo, invert

    • example：If you accidentally delete a file, you can reverse the action by pressing Ctrl+Z, which is a handy feature unless you’ve already closed the program.

  2. refute - v.

    • paraphrase：to prove something wrong

    • synonym：deny, disprove

    • example：Although the scientist presented strong evidence, her critics tried to refute her claims by pointing out minor flaws in the data.

  3. household - n./adj.

    • paraphrase：a family or group living together; related to home

    • synonym：family, home

    • example：Smart devices like thermostats are now common in many households, whereas a decade ago they were considered luxury items.

  4. overhaul - v./n.

    • paraphrase：to repair or improve completely

    • synonym：renovate, rebuild

    • example：The company plans to overhaul its website, which is outdated, so that users can navigate it more easily.

  5. wit - n.

    • paraphrase：clever humor or intelligence

    • synonym：humor, cleverness

    • example：She answered the tough question with wit, even though she was nervous, which impressed everyone in the room.

  6. holder - n.

    • paraphrase：a person or thing that holds something

    • synonym：owner, keeper

    • example：The holder of the record must defend their title unless someone else breaks their achievement.

  7. counterpart - n.

    • paraphrase：a person or thing that corresponds to another

    • synonym：equivalent, match

    • example：The CEO met with her counterpart from the rival company to discuss cooperation, whereas their teams focused on competition.

  8. spring - n./v.

    • paraphrase：the season after winter; to jump suddenly

    • synonym：leap, bounce

    • example：When flowers bloom in spring, the landscape becomes colorful, which attracts many tourists.

  9. fortunate - adj.

    • paraphrase：lucky or having good fortune

    • synonym：lucky, blessed

    • example：We were fortunate to find a parking spot near the entrance, although the lot was almost full.

  10. sneak - v.

  • paraphrase：to move quietly and secretly

  • synonym：slip, creep

  • example：He tried to sneak into the room without being noticed, but the creaky floor gave him away.

  1. vice - n.

  • paraphrase：a bad habit or moral weakness

  • synonym：sin, fault

  • example：Gambling is a vice that can ruin lives if it isn’t controlled, whereas moderate hobbies like reading are harmless.

  1. landscape - n.

  • paraphrase：the visible features of an area of land

  • synonym：scenery, view

  • example：The landscape changed dramatically after the storm, which uprooted trees and altered the river’s course.

  1. runway - n.

  • paraphrase：a strip where planes take off and land

  • synonym：airstrip, track

  • example：The pilot aborted the landing when he noticed debris on the runway, although the weather conditions were perfect.

  1. beneath - prep./adv.

  • paraphrase：under or below something

  • synonym：under, underneath

  • example：She found her lost earring beneath the couch, where it had rolled after falling off.

  1. mediate - v.

  • paraphrase：to help resolve a dispute

  • synonym：arbitrate, negotiate

  • example：The teacher had to mediate the argument between the students before it escalated into a fight.

  1. indicative - adj.

  • paraphrase：showing or suggesting something

  • synonym：suggestive, revealing

  • example：His nervousness was indicative of his lack of preparation, which became obvious during the presentation.

  1. federal - adj.

  • paraphrase：related to a central government

  • synonym：national, central

  • example：The federal agency announced new regulations, whereas local governments retained control over certain policies.

  1. preceding - adj.

  • paraphrase：coming before in time or order

  • synonym：previous, prior

  • example：The preceding chapter explained the basics, which are essential to understand the advanced topics covered later.

  1. faith - n.

  • paraphrase：strong belief or trust

  • synonym：trust, belief

  • example：She kept her faith in the team even after they lost, although many fans had given up hope.

  1. exposure - n.

  • paraphrase：the state of being exposed to something

  • synonym：contact, experience

  • example：Long exposure to sunlight can damage your skin, which is why wearing sunscreen is important.

  1. cue - n./v.

  • paraphrase：a signal to do something

  • synonym：signal, prompt

  • example：The actor missed his cue, so the scene had to be reshot, which delayed the production.

  1. alliance - n.

  • paraphrase：a union or partnership

  • synonym：partnership, coalition

  • example：The two companies formed an alliance to develop new technology, whereas their competitors worked independently.

  1. cease - v.

  • paraphrase：to stop or end

  • synonym：stop, halt

  • example：The rain finally ceased, although the ground remained wet for hours afterward.

  1. lottery - n.

  • paraphrase：a game of chance with prizes

  • synonym：raffle, draw

  • example：Winning the lottery might seem like a dream, but it can also bring unexpected problems if not managed wisely.

  1. preliminary - adj.

  • paraphrase：coming before the main event

  • synonym：initial, preparatory

  • example：The preliminary results were promising, which encouraged the team to continue their research.

  1. liberty - n.

  • paraphrase：freedom to act or think

  • synonym：freedom, independence

  • example：The new law protects individual liberty, whereas older regulations were more restrictive.

  1. threshold - n.

  • paraphrase：the entrance or starting point

  • synonym：doorway, brink

  • example：She paused at the threshold of the room, unsure whether to enter, although she had been invited.

  1. stability - n.

  • paraphrase：the state of being steady

  • synonym：balance, firmness

  • example：The economy regained stability after the crisis, which reassured investors and businesses.

  1. strike - v./n.

  • paraphrase：to hit or refuse work as protest

  • synonym：hit, protest

  • example：The workers decided to strike unless their demands for better pay were met.

  1. prosecute - v.

  • paraphrase：to take legal action against someone

  • synonym：sue, charge

  • example：The authorities will prosecute anyone who breaks the law, no matter what their position is.

  1. ambiguous - adj.

  • paraphrase：unclear or having multiple meanings

  • synonym：vague, unclear

  • example：His answer was ambiguous, which left everyone confused about what he actually meant.

  1. liable - adj.

  • paraphrase：legally responsible

  • synonym：responsible, accountable

  • example：The company is liable for any damages caused by its products, even if the fault lies with a supplier.

  1. complaint - n.

  • paraphrase：an expression of dissatisfaction

  • synonym：grievance, protest

  • example：She filed a complaint about the noisy neighbors, although they claimed they weren’t making much noise.

  1. paradise - n.

  • paraphrase：a perfect or heavenly place

  • synonym：heaven, utopia

  • example：The island was like paradise, with its white sand and clear water, which made it a popular vacation spot.

  1. outset - n.

  • paraphrase：the beginning of something

  • synonym：start, beginning

  • example：From the outset, it was clear that the project would be challenging, although the team was optimistic.

  1. condense - v.

  • paraphrase：to make shorter or more concentrated

  • synonym：compress, summarize

  • example：The editor asked her to condense the report so that it would fit into two pages, whereas the original was five.

  1. extraction - n.

  • paraphrase：the act of removing something

  • synonym：removal, withdrawal

  • example：The extraction of natural resources can harm the environment if it isn’t done responsibly.

  1. sacred - adj.

  • paraphrase：holy or highly valued

  • synonym：holy, divine

  • example：The temple is considered sacred, which is why visitors must follow strict rules when entering.

  1. demographic - n./adj.

  • paraphrase：related to population statistics

  • synonym：population, statistical

  • example：The demographic data revealed that most customers were young adults, whereas the company had assumed an older audience.

  1. dairy - n./adj.

  • paraphrase：related to milk products

  • synonym：milk, lactose

  • example：She avoids dairy because she’s lactose intolerant, although she loves cheese.

  1. variation - n.

  • paraphrase：a change or difference

  • synonym：difference, fluctuation

  • example：The variation in temperature between day and night is extreme in deserts, which makes survival difficult.

  1. dissolve - v.

  • paraphrase：to mix into a liquid or end officially

  • synonym：melt, disband

  • example：The sugar will dissolve faster in hot water, whereas salt takes longer.

  1. quota - n.

  • paraphrase：a fixed share or limit

  • synonym：limit, allocation

  • example：The factory met its production quota, which earned the workers a bonus.

  1. bleak - adj.

  • paraphrase：dreary or hopeless

  • synonym：gloomy, dismal

  • example：The future looked bleak after the company’s bankruptcy, although some employees remained hopeful.

  1. decent - adj.

  • paraphrase：acceptable or respectable

  • synonym：respectable, adequate

  • example：He offered a decent price for the car, which convinced the seller to accept the deal.

  1. breach - n./v.

  • paraphrase：a break or violation

  • synonym：violation, break

  • example：The hacker’s breach of security exposed sensitive data, which alarmed the company’s clients.

  1. triumph - n./v.

  • paraphrase：a great victory or success

  • synonym：victory, success

  • example：Their triumph in the championship was celebrated by fans, although the opponents were disappointed.

  1. participate - v.

  • paraphrase：to take part in something

  • synonym：join, engage

  • example：She was eager to participate in the debate, even though she was nervous about public speaking.

  1. originate - v.

  • paraphrase：to begin or create

  • synonym：begin, start

  • example：The tradition originated centuries ago, which is why it’s still deeply rooted in the culture.

  1. anonymous - adj.

  • paraphrase：unknown or unnamed

  • synonym：unnamed, unidentified

  • example：The donation was made by an anonymous benefactor, whose identity remains a mystery.
